[LEXICON]: [Challenging vocabulary may slow readability for non-expert readers]

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex, lengthy sentences may impede immediate readability.

[STRUCTURE]: Minor pacing shifts between dialogue-driven scenes and introspective passages.

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally complex, lengthy sentences may impede immediate clarity.
Occasionally very long, complex sentences may interrupt smooth reading flow.

[TRANSITION]: Minor abrupt shifts between scenes/dialogues (e.g., narrator’s actions to Vereker’s note).

[LEXICON]: Overly complex vocabulary (e.g., "bedlamitical," "primal plan") may impede readability.
[SYNTAX]: Frequent long, convoluted sentences (e.g., "Deep down...") disrupt flow.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between reflective commentary (e.g., "That statement...") and narrative scenes (e.g., chess analogy).
[STRUCTURE]: Dense, unmarked jumps between timeframes (e.g., past conversations vs. imaginative sequences).

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex sentence structures (e.g., "In fact I considered I showed magnanimity in not reproaching him...")
[LEXICON]: Archaic vocabulary and phrasing (e.g., "out-Herod," "grim gamblers at Monte Carlo")
[PUNCTUATION]: Infrequent line breaks or paragraph transitions in dense passages

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from Corvick’s personal life to the narrator’s literary philosophy ("For the few persons...")
[STRUCTURE]: Non-chronological jumps (e.g., referencing the telegram before fully resolving Corvick’s departure context)
[CLARITY]: Ambiguous connections between Gwendolen’s character description and the plot ("the lean ladies one had met in the temples of chance")

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex, lengthy sentence structures may impede smooth reading flow.

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt shift from literary discovery to engagement discussion without clear contextual bridge within the segment.

[COMPLEXITY]: Overly intricate sentence structures may impede smooth reading for some readers.

[STRUCTURE]: Rapid transitions between disparate events (e.g., brother’s illness to Corvick’s marriage) risk slight narrative disjointedness.

[LEXICON]: Overly formal and archaic vocabulary (e.g., "blighted bliss," "trepidation") may impede readability for modern audiences.
[SYNTAX]: Extremely long, complex sentence structures (e.g., "I had at first found a way...") risk awkward pacing.

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt shift from emotional confrontation ("It’s my life!") to literary critique and Vereker’s illness news, slightly disrupting thematic flow.
[TRANSITION]: Introduction of Drayton Deane feels somewhat convenient, with minimal contextual buildup within the segment.

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex, convoluted sentence structures (e.g., multi-clausal constructions).

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt time jumps (e.g., Vereker’s death to wife’s death) without strong transitional signaling.
[CLARITY]: Metaphorical language ("gaolers had gone off with the key") may delay comprehension.

[LEXICON]: Occasionally archaic vocabulary ("ejaculations", "propitious") may slightly hinder modern readability, though appropriate for the narrative voice.
[SYNTAX]: Very long, complex sentences (e.g., "What I saw...") require careful parsing but remain grammatically intact.

[STRUCTURE]: Brief, introspective pauses (e.g., narrator’s reflection on Deane’s marriage motives) could feel slightly abrupt but serve thematic clarity.
